questions.query: Which statement concerning compressors is correct?

options.text: A radial flow compressor is more efficient than an axial flow compressor.
A compressor stage always consists of a rotary part and a stationary part.
An axial compressor stage has a higher CR than a radial compressor stage.

options.text: The rotor increases the pressure and the velocity; the stator increases the pressure.
Both the rotor and the stator increase the pressure and the velocity.

the rotor increases the temperature; the stator increases the velocity.

options.text: when pulling the throttle lever past the idle stop that is released after touchdown.
when pulling a separate lever on the throttle up and aft.

questions.query: Oil for cooling and lubrication of the accessory gearbox comes from...

options.text:
the oil system for the IDG.

 

Note:
IDG = CSD + GEN;

CSD = constant speed drive;

GEN = AC generator;

AC = alternating current.

questions.query:

  1. cool the bleed-air;
  2. cool the hot engine oil;
  3. decrease the fuel viscosity;
  4. prevent ice crystals in the fuel line;
  5. prevent fuel waxing.

options.text: Free turbine torque and free turbine rpm.

less efficient than a modern turbofan engine.

questions.query: Compared to the same turbine engine at the test stand, the thrust of a turbine engine at an aircraft at zero speed and at equal atmospheric pressure and temperature is...

options.text: higher, because the entry speed of the compressor is higher.
higher, because the entry speed of the compressor is lower.
lower, because the engine air intake in the test stand has been designed for this situation.

questions.query: The speed at the exhaust of a turboprop is much lower than the speed at the exhaust of a turbojet because...

options.text: a high exhaust speed would result in too much engine noise.
the exhaust of a turboprop is divergent to increase the pressure thrust.
turboprops fly at lower airspeeds which does not require high exhaust speeds.
most of the combustion energy is extracted by the turbine(s).
